title: Car fanatic died ‘after breathing in toxic fumes leaking from faulty exhaust’
text:
Dillon Denton was found unresponsive behind the wheel of his car (Picture: MEN Media)

A labourer died after inhaling toxic fumes seeping from a hole in his prized car’s exhaust, relatives said as they paid tribute to the ‘gentle giant’.

Dillon Denton, 22, was found unresponsive by his best friend while parked in a Homebase carpark in Hull on March 5.

His family say he passed out due to fumes leaking from the VW Golf’s exhaust pipe.

Dillon’s sister Roxann, 28, said her brother had been planning to sell the vehicle the day he died.

She described how he ‘dreamed one day of having his own garage’ with a friend.

Dillon’s family said the labourer had passed out from car fumes due to a hole in the exhaust (Picture: Hull Daily Mail/MEN Media)

Dillon was reportedly planning to sell the Golf on the day he died (Picture: Facebook)

‘Dillon was a lovely, handsome, gentle giant with a smile that could light up even the darkest room,’ Roxann said of her ‘loving and friendly’ brother.

‘He was always doing something with his car. He was never in a dark place as long as he could drive. He would thrive off his cars and driving them.

‘As soon as he got paid he spent it all on doing a car up and selling it on for more value. He was a proper Del Boy like that.’

She told Hull Live that despite only being in his early twenties, Dillon had a tough life throughout his mid-teens.

Their parents died just two weeks apart, but Dillon found solace in his love for cars and remained strong for his family, she added.

‘He didn’t have a bad upbringing at all, just a very emotional one. He loved time to himself and was always in his car or fixing someone else’s – his car was his man cave on wheels,’ Roxann said.

Relatives paid tribute to the ‘gentle giant’ (Picture: Hull Daily Mail/MEN Media)

She described getting a frantic phone call from one of her brother’s friends who initially thought the car had run out of petrol in the carpark.

‘The windows were steamed up so you couldn’t see if anyone was inside,’ she went on.

‘Then all I heard was screaming down the other end of the phone.

‘That’s when I knew.’

Advertisement

She said her brother fell asleep, adding that the exhaust fumes seeping into the vehicle from a hole in the pipe caused her brother’s death.

‘He went through so much in his short life, he had so much more to live for, so much to look forward to,’ she said.

‘He was just chilling out in his car, reclined in his seat. He used to visit the car park to use the wifi and watch movies on his phone.

‘I’m still absolutely devastated. So many people have said nasty things about my brother at the time, but he didn’t have a bad bone in his body and would do anything for anyone. He really would.’
